instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.ADPATER_SENSE: What is ADPATER_SENSE? This is a typo of ADAPTER_SENSE When you see ADPATER_SENSE, assume they meant to type ADAPTER_SENSE.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I got this board that had no damage anywhere else besides a corroded <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>. I was and still am getting just a dim green light on the charger and I am using a genuine 85W charger. 

I have replaced the J6900 port along with <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and still I get 0.01v on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>.
I do get 16.89v on both sides of F6905 and 3.46v on Pin 1(<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL>) of <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>. 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.56v.

On Pin 5 of J6900(<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>) I get 0.617v in diode mode.

I plugged in a fake charger I had laying around and I was getting 0.77v on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>. and around 18v on Pin 1 of J6900.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> checked? <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I get 3.31v on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>.
<RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> measures the correct 2k ohms and shows 3.46v on both sides of the resistor.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: So <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> is at 3V, the <SIGNAL>ADPATER_SENSE</SIGNAL> must be too. Could be dead <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> again or short on <SIGNAL>ADPATER_SENSE</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I replaced <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> again along with <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> and I still get no green light. The only difference is that <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> is now at around .07v instead of the .01v it was before.
There is no short on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>. I still get around 0.61v in diode mode on Pin 5 of J6900.

Could it be that both of the DC-In boards I have used are bad?

Also, is it normal for F6905 to be showing 16.9v when the schematic says 18.5v?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: I hope you are 100% sure you have a good DCIN board. Also check resistance to GND on SENSE line.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
With the DCIN board inserted into j6900 I get around 1.2Megaohms on resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>.

I've plugged in 3 different DCIN boards and they all show a dim green light. One of them showed as high as 0.15v on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> and slowly goes down from there.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: What voltage do you have on PP3V42?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I have 3.46v on PP3v42.

I removed the heatsink to ultrasonic the board and I saw that <CAPACITOR>C4908</CAPACITOR> was corroded and the cap was damaged on the 3v42 side. I replaced that cap and ultrasonic'd the board. When I plug in one of my DCIN Boards now <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> shows around .90v and keeps fluctuating slowly to as high as 1.9v

I did see one or two probe points around the SMC were discolored so I'm not sure if corrosion under the SMC could be causing this.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Ok so as Duke asked what is your resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>? If your light is intermittent, I would guess crap under the SMC could be causing the issue or a dead SMC. Is the light intermittent or is it just dim?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
1.2Megaohms on resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>.

The light is dim always no matter which DCIN board I plug in.

Update: That was the resistance I was getting previously when duke asked but now when I measure I get around 1.85Mohms.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: OK lets start over and make sure we are measuring correct things here. I need to voltage on ALL pins of <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> and resistances to GND with a magsafe board connected.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
<CHIP>U6900</CHIP>
Pin 1 - 3.46v
Pin 2/3 - 0v
Pin 4 & 5 - Started around .5v and slowly went down towards .35v

It's unusual that Pin 4 is showing the same voltage as <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> but Probe 1166 and Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> is 3.46v.
There is no continuity from Pin 4 to Pin 5 nor from Pin 4 to Probe 1166

<CHIP>U6900</CHIP> Resistance to ground
Pin 1 - 1.85Megaohms
Pin 2 - 0ohms
Pin 3 - OL unconnected
Pin 4 - 1.83Megaohms
Pin 5 - 8.3 Megaohms

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Pin 4 should show the same as pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> so trace is broken.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Okay I ran a wire to the probe point and now I get a green light on the charger. The only thing is now that the board doesn't turn on. 
I get 12.55v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and I get correct voltages on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Battery charging? Light turns orange?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Yes I plugged in a battery keyboard and trackpad. The light turns orange after a couple of seconds but no fan spin and nothing happens when the power button is pressed.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Must be more corrosion. Voltage on <CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03? Clock chip had corrosion?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR>/03 are both 3.31v. The clock chip didn't have any corrosion around it.

I measured and got some more voltages.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> are both present. 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> are both showing around 2.55v 

Also, with the charger plugged in for a little while I can feel <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> getting warm but I don't feel <CHIP>U1000</CHIP> getting warm but that could be because it has a heatsink on it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Update: I did some troubleshooting and thought replacing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> would fix this but it didn't.
I get correct voltages on Pins 8, 13, 16 and 17 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.
I get 0v on Pin 1(<SIGNAL>P5VS3_ENTRIP</SIGNAL>) and 0.90v on Pin 6. Somehow I still get 2.55v on L7260 even though there is 0v on Pin 1 of <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>.
There is 0v on Pin 2 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and 0v on Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> while Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> is 3.4v.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: If <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is present then <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> should be there too. The enable for both comes from <SIGNAL>SLP_S4</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> enable is inverted by <TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR>. Measure voltages on <TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR> and  <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I have 3.3v on <SIGNAL>SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> and now I just get 0.18v on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> while <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> is 3.3v. <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is still getting slightly warm.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7911</TRANSISTOR>
Pin 1 - 3.325v
Pins 2 & 3 - 0v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>
Pin 1 - 0v
Pin 2 - 0v
Pin 3 - 0.78v
Pin 4 - 0v
Pin 5 - 0v
Pin 6 - 0v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Isn't there just a short on 5V rail? Else it must be around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>, resistance to GND on ENTRIP1?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
There is not a short on the <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> rail. In diode mode <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is showing 0.153v.
In voltage mode I get 0.18v on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and 5.02v on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>.

Resistance to GND on ENTRIP1 is 78.6 kohms

I have already replaced <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> and that didn't fix the issue. Actually before replacing <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> a couple of days ago I was getting 2.55v on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Could be <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR>, but I still suspect something around <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Possibly the FETs or a trace, check all the stuff around it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7221</TRANSISTOR> and that solved the issue and now this turns on and works fine. 

Thanks a lot Duke for your time.
